channel.title: This American Life Archive
channel.description: Autogenerated feed of the This American Life archive.

item.title: 774: The Pink House at the Center of the World
item.description: Stories from the center of this moment of history, the day it happened.

item.title: 583: It’ll Make Sense When You’re Older
item.description: Kids do not like being told it’ll make sense when they’re older. They’re pretty sure the grown-ups are wrong.

item.title: 773: The Longest Distance Between Two Points
item.description: Getting from A to B via Z.

item.title: 672: No Fair!
item.description: Stories of very small injustices and also one very big one.

item.title: 772: The Kids' Table
item.description: Kids navigating hairy situations all on their own, with no help from grown-ups.

item.title: 771: The Parents Step In
item.description: The government isn’t doing much to prevent school shootings. So parents are jumping in — and getting results.

item.description: People staring squarely at the truth, and still finding it hard to believe what they’re seeing.

item.title: 769: The Reluctant Explorer
item.description: A man is thrust into a new world he didn’t ask to visit.

item.title: 768: The Other Front Lines
item.description: Four personal stories from the war in Ukraine.

item.title: 767: Do Not Go Gentle
item.description: Stories of resistance from Hungary and Russia.

item.description: People trying to jump in and solve other people's problems.

item.title: 765: Off Course
item.description: People who know the path their lives will take until, suddenly, they don’t.

item.title: 764: School's Out Forever
item.description: The pandemic broke school. Can we ever go back?

item.title: 763: The Other Mr. President
item.description: Stories about Vladimir Putin.

item.title: 762: Apocalypse Creep
item.description: Stories from places that are slowly coming apart.

item.title: 761: The Trojan Horse Affair
item.description: A mysterious letter shocked Britain. But who wrote it?

item.title: 760: A City Walks Into an Investigation
item.description: Our story continues about the Michigan couple who walked into a police officer's house and made a disturbing discovery.

item.title: 759: A Couple Walks Into a House
item.description: An unsettling discovery in the home of a local police officer rocks an entire city.

item.title: 758: Talking While Black
item.description: People tangled up in our current racial backlash in both extreme and very personal ways.

item.title: 757: The Ghost in the Machine
item.description: People use machines to find people they lost.

item.title: 756: But I Did Everything Right
item.description: People earnestly doing what they're told, and absolutely not getting what they were promised.

item.title: 755: The Convert
item.description: The story of an FBI undercover operation from 2006 that went terribly, and became the heart of a case heard at the Supreme Court.

item.title: 754: Spark Bird
item.description: Birds—the hearts they sway, the havoc they wreck, the lives they change.

item.title: 753: What We’ve Got Here is Failure to Communicate
item.description: Getting the point across — or trying to, anyway.

item.title: 752: An Invitation to Tea
item.description: A man who was kept for 14 years in Guantanamo Bay gets out and issues an invitation to the people who kept him there.

item.title: 751: Audience of One
item.description: We bring the movies to you.

item.title: 750: The Ferryman
item.description: Stories about getting from Point A to Point B—with expert assistance.

item.title: 749: My Bad
item.description: An hour devoted to embarrassing stories.

item.title: 748: The End of the World as We Know It
item.description: What happens when one family goes all in on fighting climate change.

item.title: 747: Suitable for Children
item.description: Who thought that would be good for a kid?

item.title: 746: This Is Just Some Songs
item.description: We made you a mixtape. Don't make a big deal out of it or anything.

item.title: 745: Getting Out
item.description: People trying to escape all kinds of seemingly impossible situations.

item.title: 744: Essential
item.description: The pandemic forced jobs to change, but then the workers changed, too.

item.title: 743: Don't You Be My Neighbor
item.description: Bad neighbors. What can you do about them?

item.title: 742: The Thing I'm Getting Over
item.description: What’s recovery mean, anyway?

item.title: 741: The Weight of Words
item.description: Words mean things, but some words are especially meaningful.

item.title: 740: There. I Fixed It.
item.description: Solving problems using very extreme measures.

item.title: 739: Sisters
item.description: The bonds between sisters and how they get broken and fixed—or not.

item.title: 738: Good Grief!
item.description: People figuring out how to grieve, and doing a pretty good job of it.

item.title: 737: The Daily
item.description: An ode to life's daily practices, and what you learn from doing a thing every single day.

item.title: 736: The Herd
item.description: What happens when your own community suddenly turns on you?

item.title: 735: Bloody Feelings
item.description: Stories about the power of blood.

item.title: 734: The Campus Tour Has Been Cancelled
item.description: How the pandemic has thrown college admissions process into a kind of slow-motion chaos.

item.title: 733: Warriors in the Garden
item.description: Three friends come together to protest the murder of George Floyd. Over time, they end up in very different places.

item.title: 732: Secrets
item.description: Why we tell them, and what happens after we do.

item.title: 731: What Lies Beneath
item.description: Stories of people summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.

item.title: 730: The Empty Chair
item.description: Things lost in the past year that we haven’t talked about much.

item.title: 729: Making the Cut
item.description: There's always someone whose job it is to decide if you measure up.

item.title: 728: Lights, Camera, Christmas!
item.description: People going to great lengths to throw a special Christmas for their families.

item.title: 727: Boulder v. Hill
item.description: What the day-to-day business of saving the world looks like.

item.title: 726: Twenty-Five
item.description: Stories about people who were born the year our show first aired.

item.title: 725: Turkey in a Face Mask
item.description: Stories about food and people who set out on very particular missions with food.

item.title: 724: Personal Recount
item.description: Stories of people changing their minds.

item.title: 723: Squeaker
item.description: People grappling with an endless presidential election.

item.title: 722: The Unreality of Now
item.description: Ahead of the election, we have stories about people trying to live in the unreality that defines this moment.

item.title: 721: The Walls Close In
item.description: People who find themselves stuck in small spaces, trying to make sense of their new surroundings.

item.title: 720: The Moment After This Moment
item.description: People who are worried — or not worried enough! — about what's hurtling unstoppably towards them.

item.title: 719: Trust Me I’m a Doctor
item.description: The not-often-talked-about realm of licensing boards, and the disturbing decisions they sometimes make.

item.title: 718: Same Bed, Different Dreams
item.description: Stories of people who are tied together, but imagine radically different futures.

item.title: 717: Audience of One (2020)
item.description: At a time when going to the movies is mostly out of the question, we bring the movies to you.

item.title: 716: Trail of Tears
item.description: Writer Sarah Vowell and her twin sister retrace the Trail of Tears, the route their Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land.

item.title: 715: Long-Awaited Asteroid Finally Hits Earth
item.description: Teachers, students and parents have been bracing themselves for the start of this unprecedented school year. Now it's here.

item.title: 714: Day at the Beach
item.description: It’s the last few weeks of summer, so we’re going to the beach! This week, stories from the surf and sand.

item.title: 713: Made to Be Broken
item.description: In a pitched moment of rule-questioning, a show about rules and the people who break them.

item.title: 712: Nice White Parents
item.description: Producer Chana Joffe-Walt investigates the inordinate power of white parents at one ordinary public school.

item.title: 711: How to Be Alone
item.description: In space, in the ocean, by ourselves, or with others—we’re all just figuring out how to be apart.

item.title: 710: Umbrellas Down
item.description: As China's new national security law tightens its control over Hong Kong, we return to our episode about last fall's anti-government protests and check in to see how people are responding.

item.title: 709: The Reprieve
item.description: How Covid-19 has changed the nurses and doctors at one hospital in Detroit, and their city.

item.title: 708: Here, Again
item.description: We hear what different people said and did one weekend in reaction to the killing of George Floyd.

item.title: 707: We Are in the Future
item.description: In this moment of sorrow, protest, and rage, we offer this as a break from the dreadful present: our show about Afrofuturism.

item.title: 706: A Mess to Be Reckoned With
item.description: Lissa Yellow Bird searches for missing people. She's great at it. But then, her niece goes missing.

item.title: 705: Time Out
item.description: Our favorite stories from the football fields, boxing rings, and basketball courts of days past.

item.title: 704: Our Pulitzer-Winning Episode
item.description: What the Trump administration’s "Remain in Mexico" policy really means, on the ground, at the Mexican border.

item.title: 703: Stuck!
item.description: During a time when a lot of us feel like we are living in a holding pattern, stories of people feeling stuck.

item.title: 702: One Last Thing Before I Go
item.description: Ordinary people make last ditch efforts to get through to their loved ones.

item.title: 701: Black Box
item.description: Desperate to know what happened to his family, a man obsessively decodes the only information about them he can get.

item.title: 700: Embiggening
item.description: Sometimes a sketch of a thing needs filling in for its true significance to be known.

item.title: 699: Fiasco!
item.description: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong.

item.title: 698: The Test
item.description: Stories of people trying to rise to the challenge presented by coronavirus, in some pretty extreme situations.

item.title: 697: Alone Together
item.description: In this moment when everyone’s reaching out to the people they love, we put together a collection of family stories.

item.title: 696: Low Hum of Menace
item.description: Things do not seem fine at all, but it’s hard to say why.

item.title: 695: Everyone's a Critic
item.description: People squirming in a world where everything is rated and reviewed.

item.title: 694: Get Back to Where You Once Belonged
item.description: People looking everywhere to find a place—any place—where, for once, they don't have to be the odd man out.

item.title: 693: Abdi the American
item.description: We return to our story about Abdi Nor from 2015, with some news about his life today.

item.title: 692: The Show of Delights
item.description: In these dark times, we attempt some radical counterprogramming: a show made up entirely of stories about delight.

item.title: 691: Gardens of Branching Paths
item.description: Other universes that are just like our own, but with one small difference.

item.title: 690: Too Close to Home
item.description: For the holidays, stories of families finally addressing the thorny thing they’ve never really talked about.

item.title: 689: Digging Up the Bones
item.description: There's a lot that can be gained from unearthing the past. But it doesn't always go how you'd expect.

item.title: 688: The Out Crowd
item.description: Reports from the frontlines of the Trump administration's "Remain in Mexico" asylum policy. This episode won the first ever Pulitzer Prize given for audio journalism.

item.title: 687: Small Things Considered
item.description: Tiny letters, a very small number, and a medication that's supposed to cure shortness.

item.title: 686: Umbrellas Up
item.description: For over 100 days now, protestors in Hong Kong have taken to the streets every weekend. What it’s like to live through that.

item.title: 685: We Come From Small Places
item.description: We go to one of the biggest parties in NYC, the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn.

item.description: Stories of people who decide the only way forward — for real change — is to burn everything to the ground.

item.title: 683: Beer Summit
item.description: Two people, sitting down over a beer, hashing out their differences. Hard to imagine these days, right?

item.title: 682: Ten Sessions
item.description: A therapy that helps people work through unhealed trauma in just ten sessions.

item.title: 681: Escape From the Lab
item.description: What happens when our most ingenious creations actually make it out into the world.

item.title: 680: The Weight Of Words (2019)
item.description: Words mean things, but some words are especially meaningful — whether in a survival manual, a song lyric, or a slur.

item.title: 679: Save the Girl
item.description: People go on missions to save girls from danger. But they get so caught up that it overshadows the girl herself.

item.title: 678: The Wannabes
item.description: We hang out with the presidential candidates, in this weird early period of the election.

item.title: 677: Seeing Yourself In the Wild
item.description: Stories of those unexpected moments when we see who we really are.

item.title: 676: Here’s Looking at You, Kid

item.title: 675: I’m on TV??
item.description: What it's like to be momentarily big on the small screen.

item.title: 674: Get a Spine!
item.description: Stories of people shaking off their fear and doing what they’ve been scared to do.

item.title: 673: Left Behind
item.description: People figuring out how to move through a world in which something important has disappeared.

item.title: 672: No Fair!
item.description: Stories of very small injustices and also one very big one.

item.title: 671: Anything Can Be Anything
item.description: People connecting the dots that maybe should not be connected.

item.title: 670: Beware the Jabberwock
item.description: Stories from the upside-down world where conspiracy theorists dwell.

item.title: 669: Scrambling to Get Off the Ice

item.title: 668: The Long Fuse
item.description: People tossing words out into the world impulsively, to ignite and burn over decades.

item.title: 667: Wartime Radio
item.description: Intimate and personal dispatches from two very different battlefields.

item.title: 666: The Theme That Shall Not Be Named
item.description: Satan! In his many surprising manifestations, all around us.

item.title: 665: Before Things Went to Hell
item.description: Revisiting those moments of calm before the storm.

item.title: 664: The Room of Requirement
item.description: Stories of people who roam the stacks and find unexpected things that just happen to be exactly what they required.

item.description: Documents you don't normally think of, showing you things you didn't expect.

item.description: Stories of people who believe there is always a way. And also those who don’t.

item.description: The quiet bureaucratic war that’s even targeting legal immigrants.

item.description: Dispatches from a government agency in its tumultuous teenage years.

item.description: The clues people find when trying to make sense of a death.

item.description: Blurring the line between animal and human.

item.description: Stories about delays, including a town in Ohio known almost entirely for its speed trap.

item.description: What should we make of right-wing groups like the Proud Boys, who believe “the West is the best”?

item.description: Afrofuturism is a way of looking at black culture that’s fantastic, creative, and oddly hopeful.

item.description: Two towns grapple with the question—who do we let in?

item.description: A polygraph operator and his strange journey.

item.description: Stories about both historical and modern-day swashbucklers who loot, pillage, and question their choices.

item.description: What it's actually like to live in the confusing information landscape that is Putin's Russia.

item.title: 613: OK, I’ll Do It

item.description: Teenage girls ask for advice about their love lives, and Ira's tribute to his very grown-up friend Mary.

item.description: A show about rules and what happens when they’re vague and randomly enforced.

item.description: People going to very extreme measures to demonstrate their feelings.

item.description: We document what happened when the President’s executive order went into effect temporarily banning travel from seven countries.

item.description: Some people are super-stoked for the political changes that are coming.

item.description: Stories of people who decide to rethink the way they’ve been doing things.

item.description: People around the country talking about the coming four years after Trump's election.

item.description: Right now a lot of Republicans feel like they don’t recognize their own party.

item.description: Watching lies become the truth in the 2016 election.

item.title: 597: One Last Thing Before I Go (2016)
item.description: Ordinary people make last ditch efforts to get through to their loved ones.

item.description: Stories about people trying their best to turn themselves into something else—like a badger.

item.description: What do you do when you're thrown into a situation you’re not prepared for?

item.description: Stories of people making the wrong choice, even though the right one is staring them squarely in the eye.

item.description: Maybe it’s time to rethink the way we see being fat.

item.title: 588: Mind Games
item.description: People who try simple mind games on others and find themselves in way over their heads.

item.description: Stories about mysteries that exist in relationships we thought couldn't possibly surprise us.

item.description: Three very different stories of people not admitting the truth.

item.description: The older and wiser we get, the more bewildering our past decisions can seem.

item.title: 583: It’ll Make Sense When You’re Older
item.description: Kids do not like being told it’ll make sense when they’re older. They’re pretty sure the grown-ups are wrong.

item.title: 582: When the Beasts Come Marching In
item.description: The animals drop in and show us who's boss.

item.title: 581: Anatomy of Doubt
item.description: The story of a rape investigation gone undeniably wrong.

item.title: 580: That's One Way to Do It
item.description: The story of a young voter who defies political categorization.

item.title: 579: My Damn Mind

item.title: 578: I Thought I Knew You
item.description: A conservative radio host is completely baffled by the candidate his audience has decided to get behind this election season.

item.title: 577: Something Only I Can See

item.title: 576: Say Yes To Christmas
item.description: We go all in and bring the joy, the spontaneity, the sense that anything can happen back to Christmas.

item.description: Propaganda is complexity in the form of simplicity, if you know how to read it.

item.title: 574: Sinatra’s 100th Birthday
item.description: Stories, tributes, and attempts to understand the Chairman of the Board.

item.description: Conspiracy theories about the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin continue to shape Israel's politics and future.

item.description: Meet the people who pitch ideas for new foods and then decide which ones they're actually going to make.

item.description: A teenage girl records a remarkable story about the boyfriend who abuses her, and why it’s so hard to break up with him.

item.description: A father constructs an elaborate fantasy to occupy his 12 children.

item.description: Stories about a fallen man trying to kickstart his career with a reality show, and an awkward moment between a mom and a daughter.

item.title: 563: The Problem We All Live With - Part Two
item.description: A city goes all out to integrate its schools.

item.title: 562: The Problem We All Live With - Part One
item.description: There’s one thing that has been proven to cut the achievement gap between black and white students by half: integration.

item.title: 560: Abdi and the Golden Ticket

item.description: Stories of those very infrequent instances where people’s opinions flip on fundamental things that they believe.

item.description: The story of a guy who learned to lie for the first time in his life at age 29.

item.description: A tough group of soldiers attempts to save lives through the power of show tunes.

item.description: There's a division between people who distrust the police and people who see cops as a force for good.

item.description: When routines get too mundane, sometimes you just have to hold your breath and jump.

item.description: The pilot episode of Serial, hosted by Sarah Koenig.

item.description: Little-known and surprising stories of how all sorts of institutions began.

item.description: School board disputes are pretty common, but not like this one.

item.description: Stories where people recite words that have the power to change their lives.

item.description: Stories about how it sucks to be in limbo, and a man who absolutely loves listening to hold music.

item.description: What should a person suspected of murder say?

item.description: The story of a guy named Kirk Johnson, who started a list of Iraqis who needed to get out of their country.

item.description: People who know something's a bad idea, but convince themselves to do that thing anyway.

item.description: All of the stories in the show are things that have taken place in the last seven days.

item.description: We asked listeners to send us their best coincidence stories, and we got more than 1,300 submissions!

item.description: We spent five months at a high school in Chicago where in the last year 29 current and recent students were shot.

item.description: The proxy battle over a woman’s honor that became a presidential obsession.

item.description: Stories united by one thing: They all happened in the seven days prior to broadcast.

item.description: The This American Life staff confronts Ira about his dog, Piney.

item.description: The story of the European debt crisis is actually very surprising and dramatic.

item.description: A car plant in Fremont California that might have saved the U.S. car industry.

item.description: Stories about one person single-handedly taking charge of a situation gone wrong.

item.description: Stories of people betting on something with very bad odds.

item.description: The U.S. government spent two years on a sting operation trapping an Indian man suspected of being an illegal arms dealer.

item.description: Stories where the fine print changes everything, whether you read it or not.

item.description: When things go wrong, it's easy to pin it all on one person and watch them go down in flames.

item.description: Little-known and surprising stories of how all sorts of institutions began.

item.description: Stories of people who try to revisit their childhoods—what they find and what they do not find.

item.description: Teachers tell us about a secret room in the New York City Board of Education building called "the rubber room."

item.title: 349: Valentine’s Day 2008
item.description: Stories about couples that happen decades after the moment their eyes meet.

item.title: 348: Tough Room
item.description: We go into the writers' room at The Onion, where they start with over 600 potential headlines for their fake-news newspaper each week.

item.title: 347: Matchmakers
item.description: Making a lasting love match isn't as simple as writing a check.

item.title: 346: Home Alone

item.title: 344: The Competition
item.description: Stories of the unintended consequences of market forces.

item.title: 343: Poultry Slam 2007
item.description: Our annual program about turkeys, chickens, and fowl of all types.

item.title: 342: How to Rest in Peace
item.description: What happens to the people left behind after the detectives close the case?

item.title: 341: How to Talk to Kids
item.description: Stories of adults taking very different approaches to communicating with children.

item.title: 340: The Devil in Me
item.description: Stories of people trying to exorcize their inner demons.

item.title: 339: Break-Up
item.description: Starlee Kine tries to write the perfect break-up song with some help from Phil Collins.

item.title: 338: The Spokesman
item.description: Stories of what can happen when you go from being a private person to a public face.

item.title: 337: Man vs. History
item.description: Stories about people taking history into their own hands.

item.title: 336: Who Can You Save?
item.description: Stories about the pitfalls of trying to do the right thing.

item.title: 335: Big Wide World
item.description: When he was a teenager, Haider worked in the Iraqi Ministry of Information. He was treated like a celebrity.

item.title: 333: The Center for Lessons Learned
item.description: Four years into the Iraq War, what have we learned?

item.title: 332: The Ten Commandments
item.description: Stories of people struggling to follow the Ten Commandments from the book of Exodus.

item.title: 331: Habeas Schmabeas (2007)
item.description: Is Guantanamo Bay a camp full of terrorists, or a camp full of our mistakes?

item.title: 330: My Reputation
item.description: Stories of people trying to recover from damage to their reputations.

item.title: 329: Nice Work If You Can Get It
item.description: Stories of sudden fame, quick riches, and the downside of the dream job.

item.title: 328: What I Learned from Television
item.description: Stories recorded during our 2007 live tour, by Sarah Vowell, David Rakoff, Dan Savage, and others.

item.title: 326: Quiz Show
item.description: A man with social anxiety goes through a transformation on a TV game show.

item.title: 325: Houses of Ill Repute

item.description: Stories of Muslims and non-Muslims trying to communicate with each other and not always getting their point across.

item.description: Stories of people who are in over their heads and trying to stay afloat.

item.title: 320: What’s In A Number? — 2006 Edition
item.description: The remarkable story of what it took to determine the number of Iraqis who've died since the U.S. invasion.

item.description: Scary stories that are all true—kidnappings, zombie raccoons, and real haunted houses.

item.description: Stories of everyday people who get saddled with great power.

item.title: 316: The Cat Came Back
item.description: When something you thought was gone forever keeps returning, against all odds.

item.title: 315: The Parrot and the Potbellied Pig
item.description: Stories about animals who don't even seem like they should know each other, much less appear on the same radio show.

item.description: A grown man tries to get to the bottom of why his schoolmates threw him in a lake 20 years earlier.

item.title: 313: Parental Guidance Suggested
item.description: Stories about kids who actually want their parents looking out for them.

item.title: 312: How We Talked Back Then
item.description: We revisit two live shows we put on in the early days—one was about letters, and the other was about this then-new phenomenon called the internet.

item.title: 311: A Better Mousetrap (2006)
item.description: Stories about people trying to find new solutions to age-old problems.

item.title: 310: Habeas Schmabeas
item.description: Is Guantanamo Bay a camp full of terrorists, or a camp full of our mistakes?

item.title: 309: Cat and Mouse
item.description: Stories about the kinds of chase games that just never end.

item.title: 308: Star-Crossed Love
item.description: Stories of how love blossoms, even when (perhaps) it shouldn't.

item.title: 307: In the Shadow of the City (2006)
item.description: Stories that take place on the edge of civilization, just out of sight.

item.title: 306: Seemed Like A Good Idea at the Time
item.description: Lotto fever grips the cast of Riverdance.

item.title: 305: The This American Life Holiday Spectacular
item.description: A full-throttle, show-stopping, no-holds-barred Christmas Spectacular!

item.title: 304: Heretics
item.description: A rising star in the evangelical movement casts aside the idea of hell.

item.title: 303: David and Goliath
item.description: Variations on an old tale, with very modern consequences.

item.description: Stories about the lengths we go to make things right, and about what money can and cannot fix.

item.title: 300: What’s In A Number?
item.description: A study estimated the number of Iraqi casualties since the war began at 100,000. Most of the deaths were caused by coalition forces.

item.description: Stories about people and places that have come back to life after everything seemed lost.

item.description: How far will we go to get money? And once we've got it, what should we spend it on?

item.description: Surprising stories from survivors in New Orleans.

item.description: Some librarians in Michigan embark on an audacious act of rebranding their libraries.

item.title: 293: A Little Bit of Knowledge
item.description: Stories about the pitfalls of knowing just a little bit too little.

item.title: 292: The Arms Trader (2005)
item.description: The U.S. government spent two years on a sting operation trapping an Indian man named Hemant Lakhani.

item.description: Stories about getting back together with your parent, your spouse, your ... Brahman bull.

item.description: We spend an hour trying to remember why anyone liked the separation of church and state in the first place.

item.description: Sons and daughters get to find out the one thing they've always wanted to know about their father.

item.description: Stories about how easy it is for communication to go awry, and what the consequences can be after it does.

item.description: Stories about people who end up making choices they'd rather not make, when their options begin to run out.

item.description: After four lawyers fail to get an innocent man out of prison, his friend takes on the case himself.

item.description: Sometimes, getting your big break isn't all it's cracked up to be.

item.title: 280: In Country
item.description: What life is like for American soldiers in Iraq.

item.title: 279: Auto Show
item.description: Stories about people who love their cars, for better or for worse.

item.description: A woman starts hearing her neighbors making drug deals over her baby monitor's frequency.

item.title: 277: Apology
item.description: It's rare that a successful apology happens.

item.title: 276: Swing Set
item.description: A journey through the minds of undecided voters.

item.title: 275: Two Steps Back
item.description: The rise and fall of school reform.

item.title: 274: Enemy Camp (2004)
item.description: Behind enemy lines, sometimes people get confused about whose side they're on and how to fight the enemy.

item.description: Stories about people deciding whether to give it their all.

item.description: We leave behind the official Republican talking points and ask them to speak instead about what they actually believe.

item.description: Stories about adults struggling to figure out what is in the best interest of some child.

item.title: 270: Family Legend
item.description: Every family has its share of grudges, secrets, and bad behavior.

item.description: Letting someone else take care of you can change everything.

item.description: People who decide to try out a new life—the kind of life their parents never wanted for them.

item.description: A defense of special treatment, by people who receive it and people who give it.

item.title: 263: Desperate Measures
item.description: Stories of people stuck in unfixable situations who try desperate measures.

item.description: A son tries to help his mom in a faraway place defy the laws of medical science.

item.title: 261: The Sanctity of Marriage
item.description: A generation of researchers has revolutionized the way we see marriage.

item.description: David Rakoff tries a 20-day fast to see if it will bring him any form of enlightenment.

item.description: Sarah Vowell explains the cheerful journalism of deprivation. And other stories.

item.description: The vexing difficulty of finding the perfect gift.

item.title: 254: Teenage Embed, Part Two
item.description: Hyder returns to Afghanistan.

item.title: 253: The Middle of Nowhere
item.description: The tiny island of Nauru is at the center of several of the decade's biggest global events.

item.description: We bring you stories of turkeys, chickens, geese, ducks, fowl of all kinds, real and imagined, and their mysterious hold over us.

item.description: In his ongoing effort to write his own version of the Bible, Jonathan Goldstein retells the story of Cain and Abel.

item.description: Why is it always harder than you think it'll be?

item.description: We follow the trash from the sanitation men on the street, to the mob guys who controlled the hauling business, to the people who actually live in dumps.

item.title: 248: Like It or Not
item.description: David Rakoff guest hosts.

item.description: Four real stories in which real people invent amazingly clever solutions to their problems.

item.title: 243: Later That Same Day
item.description: Stories about what the passage of time can do to someone.

item.description: The story of a fixer for the Catholic Church and how he came to sympathize with the people that he was sent to deceive.

item.description: All kinds of little stories that we ordinarily can't use on the radio show because they are just too short.

item.description: There is a ominous information gap between the U.S. officials running the country and the Iraqi people being governed.

item.description: Jonathan Goldstein and Starlee Kine go to a karaoke club that has, along with all the songs, comedy routines for people to perform.

item.description: Stories of regime change in everyday life.

item.description: We try to figure out the paradox of the current economy, where Americans are simultaneously both losing jobs and buying new homes and cars.

item.description: Stories from the beginnings of the war in Iraq, and how it compares with wars in our country's past.

item.description: Does talking about it really help?

item.description: A man in retirement tries to start over in a new life with a new venture: a cable channel, with lots of puppies.

item.description: Real stories from three very different wars.

item.title: 231: Time to Save the World
item.description: Stories of sudden truths delivered by complete strangers.

item.description: A California teenager returns to the home country he's never known.

item.description: Stories of some of the secrets our government keeps: of imprisonment, deportation, and spying.

item.description: We still have some basic questions about why we're going to war and whether it's a good thing.

item.description: Stories of people stuck in moments that they revisit over and over again.

item.description: "Hi, middleman. Here are three splendid acts to toast your subtle virtues."

item.description: We take the laws of physics and apply them to the realm of human relationships.

item.description: Stories of people who try to convince you that the devil is there, whispering in your ear.

item.description: Stories about what happens when a new guy comes on the scene and changes everything.

item.description: When you turn someone over to the authorities, it can set into motion lots of huge, unintended consequences.

item.description: DNA evidence isn't just proving wrongdoing by criminals, it's proving wrongdoing by police and prosecutors.

item.title: 209: Didn’t Ask to Be Born
item.description: The story of an eighth grader who set himself on fire, and what led to that.

item.title: 208: Office Politics
item.description: Stories of high drama from our nation's workplaces.

item.title: 207: Special Ed
item.description: Stories about people who were told that they're different.

item.description: Life aboard an aircraft carrier stationed in the Arabian Sea supporting bombing missions over Afghanistan.

item.description: There's the thing you plan to do, and then there's the thing you end up doing.

item.description: How the American Psychiatric Association decided that homosexuality was no longer a mental illness.

item.description: Stories of faith: losing it, talking about it, constructing it, and working within it.

item.description: In a time of war, when we're all feeling a heightened sense of "us" and "them," we wanted to take up the problem of "them."

item.description: Of all the wars to win, perhaps the propaganda war is the hardest.

item.title: 199: House on Loon Lake
item.description: A young boy, an abandoned house, and the mysterious family who disappeared without a trace.

item.description: Stories of people climbing to be number one. How do they do it?

item.description: The events of September 11th, and how its meaning changes depending on who you talk to.

item.description: We try to sort out what the war in Afghanistan will be like.

item.description: Stories in the wake of the events of September 11, 2001.

item.title: 193: Stories of Loss
item.description: A collection of stories in which people try to make sense of loss.

item.title: 192: Meet the Pros
item.description: The story of one man's journey from obscurity to international professional celebrity.

item.description: There's a deep impulse in American culture that says that you can make yourself into anyone.

item.description: A modern-day fable about what happens when the free market, the media, the World War II buffs, the Neo-Nazis, and the Jews all collide over a huge Nazi tourist trap.

item.description: Stories of kids using perfectly logical arguments, and arriving at perfectly wrong conclusions.

item.title: 187: Father's Day '01
item.description: Stories of dads who are utterly human in scale.

item.title: 185: Golden Calf
item.description: Stories of people worshiping false idols, and whether that's always a bad thing.

item.description: Stories from Scott Carrier, whose strange and compelling tales sound like nothing else on the radio.

item.description: The story of what was, at one time, one of most notoriously racist and corrupt suburbs in America.

item.title: 178: Superpowers
item.description: Which is better: flight or invisibility?

item.title: 177: American Limbo
item.description: Stories of people living completely outside the grid of American life.

item.title: 176: Two Nations, One President
item.description: Democrats explain why they're having trouble getting over the 2001 election, and Republicans explain why this is so infuriating.

item.title: 175: Babysitting
item.description: A brother and sister decide to invent children to babysit, as an excuse to get out of their own house.

item.description: A live show taped for our fifth anniversary.

item.title: 173: Three Kinds of Deception
item.description: A story of self-deception, a story about deceiving others, and a story about accidental deception.

item.title: 172: 24 Hours at the Golden Apple
item.description: One day in a Chicago diner.

item.title: 171: Election
item.description: Stories for the eve of the 2000 presidential election, in which we try to look beneath the candidates' soundbites.

item.title: 170: Immigration
item.description: We look at a 1996 immigration law that is too obscure for most of us to have heard of, but which affects tens of thousands of lives in huge ways.

item.title: 169: Pursuit of Happiness
item.description: What does it mean to grow up in a country with an inalienable right to pursue happiness?

item.title: 168: The Fix Is In
item.description: We go inside the back rooms of one multinational corporation and hear the intricate workings of how they put the fix in.

item.title: 167: Memo to the People of the Future
item.description: Stories of people who are trying to control how they'll be seen by generations to come.

item.title: 166: Nobody's Family Is Going to Change
item.description: Does anyone's family ever change?

item.title: 165: Americans In Paris
item.description: David Sedaris takes Ira on a tour of his favorite spots in Paris.

item.title: 164: Crime Scene (2000)
item.description: Crime scenes and the stories they tell.

item.title: 163: Can You Fight City Hall…If You Are City Hall?
item.description: Stories of people who stand up alone for what's right, damn the consequences.

item.title: 162: Moving
item.description: Stories of people who did not want to move but circumstance forced their hands.

item.title: 161: Million Bubbles
item.description: A look at what's going on inside the individual glass and steel worlds of our cars.

item.title: 160: Character Assassination
item.description: David Foster Wallace reports on a turning point in the 2000 presidential primary.

item.title: 159: Mother’s Day
item.description: Stories of moms: How they treat us, how we treat them.

item.title: 158: Mob Mentality
item.description: The pleasure and the terror of being in a rampaging, angry mob.

item.title: 157: Secret Life of Daytime
item.description: All those people you see in the middle of the workday, in coffee shops and bookstores—why aren't they at work?

item.title: 156: What Remains
item.description: Stories of people revisiting what happened, and who they were back when.

item.title: 155: Hoaxing Yourself (2000)
item.description: Stories of people who tell a lie and then believe the lie more than anyone else does.

item.title: 154: In Dog We Trust (2000)
item.description: Exactly how much are the animals that live in our home caught up in everyday family dynamics?

item.title: 153: Dolls
item.description: The story of the book The Lonely Doll and its author, and how the author's life came to resemble something from her book.

item.title: 150: Kids As Adults

item.title: 149: Bedside Diplomacy
item.description: In the hospital, we're in a place that has its own rules and its own language and its own customs.

item.title: 148: The Angels Wanna Wear My Red Suit
item.description: The many, many different versions of Santa Claus.

item.title: 147: A Teenager's Guide to God
item.description: Oh faithless and perverse generation? How long shall I be with you? How long shall I bear with you?—Matthew 17.

item.title: 146: Urban Nature
item.description: David Rakoff visits Iceland, where the government is careful not to disturb certain boulders because some people believe that elves live there.

item.title: 145: Poultry Slam 1999
item.description: Our annual program about turkeys, chickens, fowl of all types, and their mysterious hold over our imaginations.

item.title: 144: Where Words Fail
item.description: People struggle to invent words adequate to cope with death.

item.title: 143: Sentencing
item.description: Have mandatory minimum sentences gone too far?

item.title: 142: Barbara

item.title: 141: Invisible Worlds
item.description: Stories of people who are trying to make invisible worlds visible.

item.title: 140: Family Business
item.description: What happens when the tension of family dynamics collides with the pressure of capitalist market forces.

item.title: 139: Ghosts of Elections Past
item.description: Stories designed to provide some small sense of hope about American politics.

item.title: 138: The Real Thing
item.description: Stories of people drawn to some idea, some picture, some "thing" that they just want to be.

item.title: 137: The Book That Changed Your Life
item.description: We want to believe our lives can be changed by a set of ideas contained in a book.

item.title: 136: You Are Here
item.description: Three stories, three people, and three sets of maps.

item.title: 135: Allure of Crime
item.description: Through our crimes, we express who we are.

item.title: 134: We Didn’t
item.description: It turns out that not falling in love, not doing our jobs, not spending time with our families is every bit as vivid and complicated an experience as doing something.

item.title: 133: Sales
item.description: We accompany a Hollywood screenwriter as he tries to sell a movie idea and find ourselves asking, is the art of commerce better than the art of art?

item.title: 132: Father’s Day ‘99
item.description: Photographer Joel Meyerowitz goes on a last big trip with his father, who has Alzheimer's, and his son.

item.title: 131: The Kids Are Alright
item.description: Stories in which young people take matters into their own hands, broadcast for the tenth anniversary of the crackdown at Tiananmen Square.

item.title: 130: Away From Home
item.description: Stories of people going home to places they've never been before.

item.title: 129: Advice
item.description: What if you asked people for advice and actually took ALL of the advice that everyone gave you? Sarah Vowell tried exactly that.

item.title: 128: Four Corners
item.description: We try to tell the story of life in America through portraits of life in four different states across the nation.

item.title: 127: Pimp Anthropology
item.description: A former pimp tells how he and three childhood friends became pimps in the 1970s in Oakland, California.

item.title: 126: Do-Gooders
item.description: Two do-gooders try to change things in their hometown for the better. But the more they try, the more people resent them.

item.title: 125: Apocalypse
item.description: Fundamentalist Christians and Orthodox Jews are combining forces to breed a perfect red cow that could bring about the end of the world.

item.title: 124: Welcome to America
item.description: Stories of people moving to this country: what they see and hear that those of us who were born here don't.

item.title: 123: High Cost of Living
item.description: Stories of people who choose not to live every moment to the fullest or smell the roses.

item.title: 122: Valentine’s Day ’99
item.description: Stories of impossible love and heartbreak.

item.title: 121: Twentieth Century Man
item.description: What happens if you're too good at throwing everything out and starting over?

item.title: 120: Be Careful Who You Pretend to Be
item.description: Three stories of people pretending to be something they're not, and what happens to them.

item.title: 119: Lockup
item.description: Stories of the lives of prisoners in the United States, and the lives of their families.

item.title: 118: What You Lookin’ At?
item.description: Stories about seeing and being seen, taped before a live audience in Town Hall in New York City.

item.title: 117: You Gonna Eat That?
item.description: The family table is stage on which many family dramas are played out.

item.title: 116: Poultry Slam 1998
item.description: Our annual program about turkeys, chickens, and fowl of all types.

item.title: 115: First Day
item.description: A rookie cop and a squirrel, and other stories of first days on the job.

item.title: 114: Last Words
item.description: Stories of people's last words before death.

item.title: 113: Windfall
item.description: What happens when you suddenly strike it rich?

item.title: 112: Ladies and Germs
item.description: How irrational fear of germs means that you aren't going to get good apple cider in your local supermarket this fall.

item.title: 111: Adventures in the Simple Life
item.description: I thought this was supposed to be easy.

item.title: 110: Mapping
item.description: The world redrawn by the five senses.

item.title: 109: Notes on Camp
item.description: We attempt to bridge the gap of misunderstanding between camp people and non-camp people.

item.title: 108: Truth and Lies at Age Ten
item.description: A woman who'd been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis talks about the lies she told herself as a child.

item.title: 107: Trail of Tears (1998)
item.description: Sarah Vowell re-traces the route her Cherokee ancestors took when expelled from their own land by President Andrew Jackson.

item.title: 106: Father’s Day ‘98
item.description: Stories in which fathers and their kids sit down and try to have an honest moment together.

item.title: 105: Take A Negro Home
item.description: Two stories of people who try to cross the color line, and why it's still so hard.

item.title: 104: Music Lessons
item.description: David Sedaris and Sarah Vowell on what's frustrating about music lessons, what's miraculous about them, and what they actually teach us.

item.title: 103: Scenes from A Transplant
item.description: An NPR reporter leaves her three-year-old son and heads to Omaha—for cancer treatment, and a last chance to save her life.

item.title: 102: Road Trip!
item.description: With so many songs, movies, and books about the joy of the open road, it's hard to take just a normal road trip without huge expectations.

item.title: 101: Niagara
item.description: The story of a town that started with something huge—the falls—and built nothing lasting from it.

item.title: 100: Radio
item.description: A radio show about what makes radio so great, and what makes it so terrible.

item.title: 99: I Enjoy Being A Girl, Sort Of
item.description: Variations on what it means to be a girl and what it means to be a woman.

item.title: 98: Throwing the First Punch
item.description: Stories about what it means to be a person who throws the first punch, and how hard it is to give up.

item.title: 97: Death to Wacky
item.description: David Sedaris tells true stories of photographers who try to take pictures of him which will make him seem "wacky." That, and other stories of wackiness.

item.title: 96: Pinned by History
item.description: Stories of people who were lifted out of everyday life, thrown into much bigger events, and how that made sense of what they did years after the fact.

item.title: 95: Monogamy
item.description: Stories of people struggling to redefine monogamy, to stay monogamous, and what we should make of these ad hoc experiments in everyday life.

item.title: 94: How To
item.description: Ira teaches Sarah Vowell how to drive with some advice from the hosts of Car Talk.

item.title: 93: Valentine’s Day ’98
item.description: Stories about couples that all take place decades after that moment their eyes first meet.

item.title: 92: Leave the Mask On
item.description: When someone tries to tell you a little bit more about themselves than you'd really rather know.

item.title: 91: Escape the Box
item.description: Stories of people trying to escape the box of their own lives, and create new lives.

item.title: 90: Telephone
item.description: The story of a teenager, illegal drug use, lying, stealing, and a kid's life changed completely when he heard how he sounded on the phone.

item.title: 89: Sibling Rivalry
item.description: Stories about people who are destined to fight: brothers and sisters.

item.title: 88: Numbers
item.description: People trying to use numbers to describe things that should not be quantified.

item.title: 87: A Very Special Sedaris Christmas
item.description: Holiday stories from David Sedaris and Julia Sweeney.

item.title: 86: How to Take Money from Strangers
item.description: A con man who's so good he's thanked.

item.title: 85: Poultry Slam 1997
item.description: Chickens and turkeys are a mirror of ourselves.

item.title: 84: Harold
item.description: The story of Harold Washington and the white backlash that was set off when he became Chicago's first black mayor.

item.title: 83: One of Us
item.description: Stories of outsiders who want to be insiders, and vice versa.

item.title: 82: Haunted
item.description: Stories of people who are haunted, not by ghosts or phantoms, but by other people.

item.title: 81: Guns
item.description: Americans who love their guns, and the Americans who love them.

item.title: 80: Running After Antelope
item.description: Scott Carrier with the latest installment in his 12-year quest to chase down and catch an antelope.

item.title: 79: Stuck in the Wrong Decade
item.description: People stuck in the wrong decade, or simply carrying a lot of the props from another decade.

item.title: 78: How Bad Is Bad?
item.description: Ira Glass talks to three teenage boys who buy computer equipment using stolen credit card numbers. And other stories.

item.title: 77: Pray
item.description: Can the secular world and the religious world understand each other?

item.title: 76: Mob
item.description: The mob as portrayed in movies, and as it is in real life. And its hold over us.

item.title: 75: Kindness of Strangers
item.description: A locksmith tells the story of an act of kindness he committed, hoping for a small reward. That, and other stories of kindness in New York City.

item.title: 74: Conventions
item.description: What happens when people with a common interest gather in fluorescent-lit halls? Sometimes they drive each other crazy, sometimes they fall in love.

item.title: 73: Blame It on Art
item.description: Mona LisaThe darker side of the art world: petty jealousies, competitiveness, failure.

item.title: 72: Trek
item.description: The story of two Americans—one white, one black—who go to South Africa and have very different opinions about what they find.

item.title: 71: Defying Sickness
item.description: A man goes on a last big trip with his father who has Alzheimer's.

item.title: 70: Other People's Mail
item.description: Four stories of people who read other people's mail, and what happens to them once they get caught up in these other lives.

item.title: 69: Dream House
item.description: Parents moving the family to some new place, hoping it works out for the kids.

item.title: 68: Lincoln's Second Inaugural
item.description: We look at the legacy of the most moving, poetic inaugural speech in American history.

item.title: 67: Your Dream, My Nightmare
item.description: An interracial couple takes a plantation tour. And other stories in which someone's dream is someone else's nightmare.

item.title: 66: Tales from the Net
item.description: Listeners sent us samples of what they're finding on the internet, including postings from Usenet groups, favorite web pages, and their own email.

item.title: 65: Who's Canadian?
item.description: Canadians claim they're no different from red-blooded Americans. We put their position to the test.

item.title: 64: Summer
item.description: We want summer to be this wonderful break, but so often it fails to deliver.

item.title: 63: One Thing
item.description: A man tries to run for President as a utopian nudist, and other stories of people whose lives are organized around one thing.

item.title: 62: Something for Nothing
item.description: Twenty-four people put one hand on a Hardbody pickup truck and wait...until only one person is left standing. Plus other stories of people trying to get rich quick.

item.title: 61: Fiasco! (1997)
item.description: Stories of when things go wrong. Really wrong.

item.title: 60: Business of Death
item.description: Stories of people for whom death is a job—undertakers, homicide detectives, slaughterhouse workers, and others.

item.title: 59: Fire
item.description: Stories about people who are not afraid of fire, though perhaps they should be.

item.title: 58: Small Towns
item.description: The claustrophobia, freedom, and yearning people feel in small towns.

item.title: 57: Delivery
item.description: Stories about the delivery business and the people in it: UPS men, bike messengers, FedEx dispatchers.

item.title: 56: Name Change
item.description: Name changes are particularly American stories: they're the dream of starting over with a clean slate.

item.title: 55: Three Women and the Sex Industry
item.description: Radio producer Sandy Tolan was supposed to do a documentary about strippers with an aspiring writer—and stripper—named Susan. But then Susan disappeared.

item.title: 54: Sinatra
item.description: Stories, tributes, and attempts to understand the Chairman of the Board.

item.title: 53: Valentine’s Day ‘97
item.description: Stories about our parents falling in love.

item.title: 52: Edge of Sanity
item.description: Stories about the border between mental health and mental illness.

item.title: 51: Animals Die, People Ponder
item.description: Stories of people who handle dead animals. (Don't worry—it's not as gross as it sounds.) Featuring a story by George Saunders.

item.title: 50: Shoulda Been Dead
item.description: A man decides to live as if he'll die in six months. That, and other stories of starting life over.

item.title: 49: Animals
item.description: Stories about the animalness of animals, the irreducible ways in which they are not human.

item.title: 48: Justice
item.description: A portrait of Americans at the International Tribunal.

item.title: 47: Christmas and Commerce
item.description: The intersection of Christmas and retail, including David Sedaris's "Santaland Diaries."

item.title: 46: Sissies
item.description: A family where the father was one kind of sissy and the son was another kind, and how the family was destroyed despite the fact that no one wanted it to be.

item.title: 45: Media Fringe
item.description: People struggling at the fringes of our nation's infotainment industry.

item.title: 44: Poultry Slam 1996
item.description: Stories about turkeys, chickens, ducks, and fowl of all kinds.

item.title: 43: Faustian Bargains
item.description: People who made a deal with the devil.

item.title: 42: Get Over It!
item.description: Trying to forget the past and move on.

item.title: 41: Politics
item.description: Stories of the election you can't hear anywhere else.

item.title: 40: Lessons
item.description: Spalding Gray on finding the zen of skiing.

item.title: 39: Halloween
item.description: Stories of things that are supposed to be scary, but aren't.

item.title: 38: Simulated Worlds
item.description: Civil War reenactments, wax museums, simulated coal mines, fake ethnic restaurants, an ersatz Medieval castle, and other re-created worlds that thrive all across America.

item.title: 37: The Job That Takes Over Your Life
item.description: Scott Carrier got a job interviewing schizophrenics. After awhile, he began to wonder if he was a schizophrenic himself.

item.title: 36: Letters
item.description: We took out advertisements in Chicago inviting people to share letters they've received, sent, or found.

item.title: 35: Fall Clearance Sale
item.description: Stories that haven't fit into any of our regular "theme" shows.

item.title: 34: Democratic Convention
item.description: Unusual stories from the 1996 Democratic Convention in Chicago.

item.title: 33: A Night at the Wiener Circle
item.description: Ira Glass spends a night at one of the most boisterous hot dog stands in the nation: Chicago's Wiener Circle.

item.title: 32: Republican Convention
item.description: Unusual stories about day-to-day life at the Republican Convention.

item.title: 31: When You Talk About Music
item.description: Stories of people whose lives are transformed by music.

item.title: 30: Obsession
item.description: What happens when a little idea starts to control you.

item.title: 29: Bob Dole
item.description: Unusual perspectives on the presumptive Republican nominee.

item.title: 28: Detectives
item.description: David Sedaris recalls the days when his mother and sister played armchair detective.

item.title: 27: The Cruelty of Children
item.description: A story of youthful backstabbing by David Sedaris.

item.title: 26: Father's Day '96
item.description: Ira's own father, Barry Glass, co-hosts this special Father's Day show.

item.title: 25: Basketball
item.description: The Chicago Bulls and their grip on Chicagoans' hearts and lives during the NBA playoffs.

item.title: 24: Teenaged Girls
item.description: Girls who have to figure out how they're going to act when the ground rules are constantly shifting.

item.title: 23: Drama Bug
item.description: Stories of the people who fall for a life in the theater.

item.title: 22: Adult Children
item.description: Stories of the difficult relationships between parents and their grown children.

item.title: 21: Factions
item.description: Friends get together to start a business, start a church, do political action together. And after a while, they start fighting and split up.

item.title: 20: From A Distance
item.description: Stories of admiring someone from afar, and trying to get closer to them.

item.title: 19: Rich Guys
item.description: Men who had comfortable, decent lives, yet decided to do something wild and eccentric.

item.title: 18: Liars
item.description: A girl who adored her father tries to figure out what to think after he takes some of her college money and lies to her about it.

item.title: 17: Name Change / No Theme
item.description: Our first show as This American Life.

item.title: 16: Economy
item.description: Politics, the economy, and the big picture.

item.title: 15: Dawn
item.description: Jack Hitt stumbles onto an epic story of the Old South and changing cultural norms in America.

item.title: 14: Accidental Documentaries
item.description: Stories made from old recordings found in attics and thrift stores.

item.title: 13: Love
item.description: The dream of true love and the difficulties with achieving and maintaining that dream.

item.title: 12: Animals
item.description: The animalness of animals, and the irreducible ways in which they are not human.

item.title: 11: Enemies
item.description: A friendship between two young boys that was destroyed through the manipulative acts of one of them.

item.title: 10: Double Lives
item.description: People living their lives, just like the rest of us. Plus an extra life.

item.title: 9: Julia Sweeney
item.description: Julia Sweeney and her brother found out they each had cancer six months apart.

item.title: 8: New Year
item.description: Reflecting back on 1995.

item.title: 7: Quitting
item.description: People who quit everything in their lives that they hated.

item.title: 6: Christmas
item.description: A Christmas radio play by David Sedaris.

item.title: 5: Anger and Forgiveness
item.description: Stories that reveal the societal "trend" toward anger and away from genuine forgiveness.

item.title: 4: Vacations
item.description: Vacations gone awry—or perhaps vacations that never should have happened.

item.title: 3: Poultry Slam 1995
item.description: Decrying the wonders of turkeys, chickens, and other fowl.

item.title: 2: Small Scale Sin
item.description: Three teenage boys tell us about their forays into low-level credit card hacking.

item.title: 1: New Beginnings
item.description: Our very first broadcast.
